page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Wrestlingworth was not mentioned in the origional Domesday Survey. The earliest written record in 1150 gives its spelling as "Wraslingewrd". This meant "the enclosure belonging to Wraestel". By 1234 the village was known as Wrestlingworth. In the early 13th century there were two manors. One was first mentioned in 1138-84 when Simon, Earl of Northampton and Huntingdon, granted the manor of Wrestlingworth to Reginald de Dammartin, Count of Boulogne. Henry VII gave it to his mother in 1485. On her death it passed to Henry VIII. In 1722 Sir George Downing owned the manor and by the next century part of the village was owned by Downing College.
